dataset.title: Insect Herbivores on Goldenrods (Solidago altissima) in the Finger Lakes Region, New York, USA

abstract.para:
Insect herbivores on the Goldenrod Solidago altissima were censused in spring and autumn over a sixteen year period (1981-1996) in old fields in the Finger Lakes region of New York State, USA. The digitized data included here are from the spring and autumn censuses of 1981. The original data from all years are archived and publicly available at the Cornell University Llibrary, Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections: Richard Root Papers, #14-35-4058.
Previous publications based on these data focused on a number of questions: (1) (a) to what extent the functional structure of the community was maintained by compensatory changes in the densities of the member species, and (b) whether certain traits were associated with a species' tendency to fluctuate in density or to dominate the community (Root, R.B. and N. Cappuccino, 1992) and (2) in combination with insect removal experiments, measuring temporal variation in herbivore pressure and plant phenotypic responses to different levels of insect herbivory (Root, R.B., 1996).

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Finger Lakes Region of central New York State, United States of America

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology

section.title: All methods
section.para: Methods described here are excerpted from Root and Cappucino (1992). More detailed methods are included with the original data, archived at the Cornell Unversity library. ÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂƒÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂƒÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â‚ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â¢ÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂƒÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â‚ÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â‚ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂƒÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â‚ÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â‚ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂœCensuses were conducted in several old fields around Cayuga Lake in south central New York State (see Fig. 1 in Root & Cappucino, 1992). The fields were selected using the following criteria: (a) the area containing goldenrods exceeded 7000 M2, (b) the Solidago altissima population exceeded 5000 ramets, (c) the site was well isolated from pesticide drift and road dust, (d) the area was protected from disturbance (none of these fields were mowed, burned, or trampled during the study), (e) the successional age of the site was such that the goldenrod clones were well established but woody plants were small and scattered (none of the plants sampled in this study grew in the shade of woody plants), (f) the site was relatively level and well drained, and (h) other large stands of goldenrods grew within a 1-km radius of the field. We did not sample any "linear" stands of goldenrods that grow along roadsides, ditches, or fences. We observed no obvious successional changes in the vegetation structure at our study sites over the course of the investigation. The survey in 1981 included 16 sites. We visited each site in both the first week of June and mid-September. The exact timing of each census was determined by phenological indicators rather than calendar date; the June census was begun when the majority of Trirhabda virgata larvae (a dominant herbivore species) were beginning to molt to third instar, and the September census was begun when S. altissima reached peak bloom. At each site, two parallel transects, 125 m long and 20 m apart, were walked during each census period. Every fifth stride, a single goldenrod stem was chosen haphazardly (by taking the nearest ramet to a spot on the ground selected by pointing a meter stick while walking with the eyes focused on the opposite side of the transect), measured, and searched carefully for herbivores. Care was taken to observe any insect that flew or dropped from the plant as we approached. Fortunately, most insects in this fauna are relatively placid and remain on the plant, even when it is cut and handled. Fifty stems from each field were sampled in June; forty were sampled in September. After each September sample, we searched an additional 60 stems per site for stem gall-making insects. All invertebrate herbivores were recorded. In 1981 and 1982 representatives of each taxon were collected and brought back to the laboratory to be dried and weighed. We were able to identify only a portion of the fauna to species in the field; those we could not were lumped into larger taxonomic groups. As the study progressed, we were able to recognize accurately more species in the field. Thus some species that were lumped initially were counted separately in later years.ÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂƒÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂƒÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â‚ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â¢ÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂƒÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â‚ÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â‚ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂƒÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â‚ÃƒÂƒÃ‚ÂƒÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â‚ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â

attribute.attributeDefinition: Year in which the data were collected.
Season during which the data were collected.
Date of data collection.
Site of data collection.
Initials of the individual who recorded the data.

A group of ten stems recorded together. For the purpose of creating a unique ideitifier for every stem recorded. Each block of ten within each locality has been given a letter (from A to D) that, along with the stem number (1-10), date, and site locality forms a unique identifier. The group number was written in pencil on the original data sheets in 2013.

A number from 1-10 given to each stem in each group. For the purpose of creating a unique ideitifier for every stem recorded. Each block of ten stems within each locality has been given a letter (from A to D) that, along with the stem number (1-10), date, and site locality forms a unique identifier.
Height of the stem, in centimeters.
Number of ball galls recorded on the plant.
Number of scarred galls recorded on the plant.
Number of spindle galls recorded on the plant.
Number of rosette galls recorded on the plant.
Number of leaf galls recorded on the plant.
Number of leaf mines recorded on the plant.
Number of red aphids recorded on the plant.
Presence of a red aphid colony on the plant?
Number of green aphids recorded on the plant.
Presence of a red aphid colony on the plant?
Condition of stem at the time of recording.
Year in which the data were collected.
Season in which the data were collected.
Date on which the data were collected. Taken from recording sheets.
Location of data collection. Information taken from recording sheets.
Initials of the person who recorded the data. Taken from recording sheets.

Number of stems per square-meter. The table containing these data is stored in a different filing folder (Ã¢Â€ÂœCS Ã¢Â€Â™80 Ã¢Â€Â“ Ã¢Â€Â™82Ã¢Â€Â) from the rest of the 1981 data. This file folder has a tab labeled Ã¢Â€ÂœSpring 81Ã¢Â€Â. The names of the locations do not entirely match up with the rest of the dataset. One of the three Whipple plots has been a different name (but the other two are consistent), but I assumed it was the same one as in the main dataset. Instead of having a Ã¢Â€ÂœRichford Hill,Ã¢Â€Â there is a Ã¢Â€ÂœHartford Hill.Ã¢Â€Â Is this a mistake on RBRÃ¢Â€Â™s part? Some of the location are marked Ã¢Â€ÂœND,Ã¢Â€Â which we presume to mean Ã¢Â€ÂœNo Data.Ã¢Â€Â Some have blank recording boxes. In the spreadsheet, I kept Ã¢Â€ÂœNDÃ¢Â€Â as Ã¢Â€ÂœND, labeled the blank ones Ã¢Â€ÂœN/AÃ¢Â€Â, and left blank any locations that were not mentioned in the table (but were part of the main dataset).

Stems were recorded in groups of ten; generally, there were five groups per location (though sometimes fewer). For the purposes of giving each stem a unique identifier in the spreadsheet, we assigned each group of ten stems a letter from A to E.
Stems were recorded in groups of ten. For the purpose of giving each stem a unique identifier in the spreadsheet, we assigned each stem within a group a number from 1 to 10.

textDomain.definition: ID number within a letter-defined group

attribute.attributeDefinition: Total number of Trirhabda individuals recorded on a stem. Though the original data sometimes marked different life stages of the individuals observed, this recording was inconsistent, so we paid attention only to the total number. We counted a Trirhabda mine as one individual, which was how Root counted them. Gowan occasionally filled blank cells in this column with dashes, but we chose to remove these as we were unsure of their meaning and as Root did not give them a numeric value when counting individuals.

Total number of Microrhopala individuals recorded on a stem. Though the original data sometimes marked different life stages of the individuals observed, this recording was inconsistent, so we paid attention only to the total number.

Total number of Exema individuals recorded on a stem. Though the original data sometimes marked different life stages of the individuals observed, this recording was inconsistent, so we paid attention only to the total number.

Total number of Ophraella individuals recorded on a stem. Though the original data sometimes marked different life stages of the individuals observed, this recording was inconsistent, so we paid attention only to the total number.

Total number of Philaneus individuals recorded on a stem. Though the original data sometimes marked different life stages of the individuals observed, this recording was inconsistent, so we paid attention only to the total number.

Total number of Pubilia individuals recorded on a stem. Though the original data sometimes marked different life stages of the individuals observed, this recording was inconsistent, so we paid attention only to the total number.

Total number of Trichotape individuals recorded on a stem. Though the original data sometimes marked different life stages or sizes of the individuals observed, this recording was inconsistent, so we paid attention only to the total number.

When evidence of Trichotapes-caused damage was observed on a stem, but no individuals were observed, Ã¢Â€ÂœsignÃ¢Â€Â or Ã¢Â€ÂœdamageÃ¢Â€Â was recorded in the appropriate datasheet box. Boxes marked this way did not contribute to the total numerical count of individuals. We moved these notes into their own column and labeled it Ã¢Â€Âœdamage,Ã¢Â€Â as that is more specific and matches up with RBRÃ¢Â€Â™s later notation system. There are three possible options for this column: Y (for Ã¢Â€ÂœyesÃ¢Â€Â) when Ã¢Â€ÂœsignÃ¢Â€Â or Ã¢Â€ÂœdamageÃ¢Â€Â was recorded on the original recording sheet. - (dash) when no damage was recorded and there were also no individuals recorded. U (for Ã¢Â€ÂœunknownÃ¢Â€Â) when no damage was recorded, but there was a number given for individuals, as the recorders did not seem to record damage when they found individuals.

codeDefinition.definition: No damage recorded and no individuals observed
Unknown: no damage was recorded, but individuals were observed on stem (see definition of attribute).

attribute.attributeDefinition: Total number of aphids recorded on a stem. Though the original data sometimes marked different life stages (e.g. nymph, alate) and color (e.g. green/GN) of the individuals observed, this recording was inconsistent, so we paid attention only to the total number.
Height of the stem in centimeters. Taken from recording sheets.

unit.name: Individuals per stem
unit.description: Number of individual insects or galls seen on a Solidago stem.
